cxro.common.device.motion

Interface Stage

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Device

    public interface Stage
extends Device
    Interface for N Dimensional Motion Devices.

    This describes a generic interface for both coordinated and independent axes devices. The intention is to make it possible, at the top level, to do basic motion control for all motion systems. As such, it does not try to do all possible motion combinations.

    REVISION NOTES:
    2014-11-13 : Initial.
    2014-11-19 : release candidate.
    2014-12-20 : simplify return values.

      • getAxesIsEnabled

        boolean getAxesIsEnabled()
                  throws java.io.IOException
        Test for ENABLED condition, all axes.

        This is a logical AND of all individual axis ENABLED conditions. Most motion commands will return exceptions if the stage is not enabled.

        Returns:
        true if ENABLED
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • getAxesIsLinear

        boolean[] getAxesIsLinear()
                   throws java.io.IOException
        Test for LINEAR motion, all axes.

        LINEAR = NOT ROTARY. If true, units are in mm. If false, units are in mrad.

        Returns:
        array of axis linear vs rotary parameters, true if LINEAR.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • getAxesIsAtLimit

        boolean getAxesIsAtLimit()
                  throws java.io.IOException
        Test for AT_LIMIT condition, all axes.

        One of the axis limit switches is active.

        This is a logical OR of all individual axis AT_LIMIT conditions. Use getAxesStatus to determine individual limit switch status.

        Returns:
        true if AT_LIMIT.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • getAxesSwitches

        byte[] getAxesSwitches()
                throws java.io.IOException
        Get status of hardware switches, all axes.

        This method returns an array of bytes that represent the current status of the hardware switches on the stage.

        The return byte value, for each axis, is indexed as follows:

        • bit 0x01 : FORWARD_LIMIT
        • bit 0x02 : REVERSE_LIMIT
        • bit 0x04 : HOME_SWITCH
        When set, the switch is active.

        Ex:
           byte[] switches = myStage.getStageSwitches();
           if((switches[0] & 0x02) == 1) // test Reverse_Switch for axis 0
              //throw error or act accordingly.

        Returns:
        array of current switch settings.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO exception

      • getAxesPosition

        double[] getAxesPosition()
                  throws java.io.IOException
        Get position, all axes.

        Return array of axis positions.

        Returns:
        array of axis positions (in scaled units).
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • setAxesPosition

        void setAxesPosition(double[] pos)
              throws java.io.IOException
        Define current position, all axes.

        Sets the current position to any defined position in the SCALED coordinate system.

        NOTE1: This does not modify the UNSCALED controller position; rather, it modifies the OFFSET so that:

        POS_SCALED = (POS_UNSCALED - OFFSET)/SCALE

        NOTE2: This will have an effect on the software limits. The unscaled value for the soft limits will remain fixed, but the scaled value for the software limits will now be:

        LIMIT_SCALED = (LIMIT_UNSCALED - OFFSET)/SCALE

        Parameters:
        pos - New value for current position.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • getAxesIsBusy

        boolean getAxesIsBusy()
               throws java.io.IOException
        Test for BUSY condition, all axes.

        If true, the controller is busy with another operation. This is a logical OR of all individual axis BUSY conditions.

        Returns:
        true if BUSY
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

        boolean getAxesIsInitialized()
                      throws java.io.IOException
        Test for INITIALIZED status, all axes.

        This is the logical AND of all individual axis INITIALIZED conditions. Most motion commands are prohibited until all axes are initialized.

        Returns:
        true if INITIALIZED
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

                 throws java.io.IOException

        MOVING = NOT STOPPED. This is a logical OR of all individual axis MOVING conditions.

        Returns:
        true if MOVING
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

                throws java.io.IOException

        READY = DONE & STOPPED & ENABLED & INITIALIZED

        Returns:
        true if READY

      • getAxesIsReachable

        boolean getAxesIsReachable(double[] dest)
                    throws java.io.IOException
        Determine if the destination is reachable, all axes.

        For a system of independent axes, this will be a simple test of limits for the system. For more complicated systems, this will involve a comparison with the working envelope.

        Parameters:
        dest - multiaxis destination.
        Returns:
        true if destination is within the working envelope.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception Generic IO exception

        current axis status objects

      • abortAxesMove

        Result abortAxesMove()
              throws java.io.IOException
        Stop motion, maximum deceleration, for all axes.

        This operation can take some time. The calling program should use getAxesIsMoving to determine when motion is stopped and getAxesIsReady to determine when motion can be re-initiated.

        Returns:
        Result
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • stopAxesMove

        Result stopAxesMove()
             throws java.io.IOException
        Stop motion, normal deceleration, all axes.

        This operation can take some time. Therefore it is handled by a separate thread in the driver.

        An immediate command response is returned. The calling program should use getAxesIsMoving to determine when motion is stopped and getAxesIsReady to determine when motion can be initiated.

        Returns:
        Result
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • initializeAxes

        java.util.concurrent.Future<Result> initializeAxes()
                                            throws java.io.IOException
        Initialize all axes.

        This initiates an initialization operation for all axes. In most cases, this is a homing operation which finds either the home limit or encoder index and sets the UNSCALED position to zero.

        If the controller is aware of the system configuration, this method might involve a more complex, coordinated, sequence of operations arriving at the final state.

        An asynchronous Future<Result> is returned.

        The calling program should test this object for isDone to determine when the move is complete. The result is then available by calling get.

        Returns:
        future Result at end of operation.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • moveAxesAbsolute

        java.util.concurrent.Future<Result> moveAxesAbsolute(double[] dest)
                                              throws java.io.IOException
        Absolute move, all axes.

        Coordinated move of all axes to target destination. An asynchronous Future<Result> is returned.

        The calling program should test this object for isDone to determine when the move is complete. The result is then available by calling get.

        Parameters:
        dest - move destination
        Returns:
        future Result at end of move.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • moveAxesRelative

        java.util.concurrent.Future<Result> moveAxesRelative(double[] dist)
                                              throws java.io.IOException
        Relative move, all axes.

        Coordinated move of all axes by a specified distance from current position. An asynchronous Future<Result> is returned.

        The calling program should test this object for isDone to determine when the move is complete. The result is then available by calling get.

        Parameters:
        dist - move distance
        Returns:
        future Result at end of move.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • getAxesDestination

        double[] getAxesDestination()
                     throws java.io.IOException
        Returns the current target destination, all axes.

        If motion is completed, the target equals current position.

        Returns:
        destination - current target destination, all axes.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO exception

      • setAxesDestination

        Result setAxesDestination(double[] dest)
                   throws java.io.IOException
        Set target destination, all axes.

        This updates the axes destinations and, possibly, initiates a move. The target destination is specified by the input array dest.
        With most axes, the destination can be updated while a prior move is in progress. With some stages, if the destination cannot be updated, this method will return an BUSY status.

        Only the immediate command status is returned. Motion completion should be polled independently using getAxesIsReady.

        Parameters:
        dest - move destination, SCALED
        Returns:
        Result at start of move.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO exception

      • getAxisName

        java.lang.String getAxisName(int axis)
                      throws java.io.IOException
        Return single axis device name.

        The name is a readonly parameter that is used to signify the path to configuration data that is maintained by the driver. It represents a hierarchical path to the axis data via the associated component and device elements.

        For instance, the X axis of the zoneplate stage that is associated with the SHARP endstation, would be given the following name:

        • cxro/sharp/zp_stage/x

        Parameters:
        axis - axis number [0..(size-1)]

        Returns:
        Full device name
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • disableAxis

        Result disableAxis(int axis)
            throws java.io.IOException
        Disable single axis.

        This will turn the axis motor off.

        NOTE: This will not assure that the motor is first stopped, nor that a brake will be applied. This must be performed separately by the application program before calling this method.

        Parameters:
        axis - axis number [0..(size-1)]
        Returns:
        Result
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • getAxisSwitches

        byte getAxisSwitches(int axis)
              throws java.io.IOException
        Get status of hardware switches, single axis.

        This method returns a byte that represent the current status of the hardware switches for a single axis on the controller.

        The return byte value, for this axis, is indexed as follows:

        • bit 0x01 : FORWARD_LIMIT
        • bit 0x02 : REVERSE_LIMIT
        • bit 0x04 : HOME_SWITCH
        When set, the switch is active.

        Ex:
           byte switches = myStage.getAxisSwitches(0);
           if((switches & 0x02) == 1) // test Reverse_Switch for axis 0
              //throw error or act accordingly.

        Parameters:
        axis - axis number [0..(size-1)]
        Returns:
        current switch settings.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO exception

        POS_SCALED = (POS_UNSCALED - OFFSET)/SCALE

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        SCALED position
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • setAxisPosition

        void setAxisPosition(int axis,
                     double pos)
              throws java.io.IOException
        Define current position, for single axis.

        Sets the current position to pos.

        NOTE: this does not modify the internal UNSCALED controller position; rather, it modifies the software managed OFFSET such that:
        POS = (POS_UNSCALED - OFFSET)/SCALE

        Parameters:
        axis - axis number [0..(size-1)]
        pos - New value for current position.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • getAxisIsReady

        boolean getAxisIsReady(int axis)
                throws java.io.IOException
        Test for READY status, single axis.

        If true, the axis is ready to receive move commands.

        isReady = isEnabled && !isFaulted && !isBusy If true, the axis is ready to receive move commands.

        Parameters:
        axis - axis number [0..(size-1)]
        Returns:
        true if READY
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • getAxisIsReachable

        boolean getAxisIsReachable(int axis,
                           double dest)
                    throws java.io.IOException
        Determine if the destination is reachable, single axis.

        For a system of independent axes, this will be a simple test of limits for the given axis. For more complicated systems, this will involve a comparison with the working envelope.

        Parameters:
        axis - axis number [0..(size-1)]
        dest - single axis destination.
        Returns:
        true if destination is within the working envelope.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception Generic IO exception

        Result abortAxisMove(int axis)

        Stop motion, maximum deceleration, for all axes.

      • stopAxisMove

        Result stopAxisMove(int axis)
             throws java.io.IOException
        Stop motion, normal deceleration, single axis.

        This operation can take some time. Therefore it is handled by a separate thread in the driver.

        An immediate command response is returned. The calling program should use getAxesIsMoving(axis) to determine when motion is stopped and getAxesIsReady(axis) to determine when motion can be initiated.

        Parameters:
        axis - axis number [0..(size-1)]
        Returns:
        Status
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception
        See Also:
        Result

      • initializeAxis

        java.util.concurrent.Future<Result> initializeAxis(int axis)
                                            throws java.io.IOException
        Initialize single axis.

        This initiates an initialization operation for a single axis. In most cases, this is a homing operation which finds either the home limit or encoder index and sets the UNSCALED position to zero. For most coordinated axes systems require simultaneous initialization of all axes. In this case, this method will return an UnsupportedOperationException.

        This operation typically takes a long time and generally spawns a background thread to perform the operation. The calling program should use getAxesIsBusy(axis) and getAxesIsInitialized(axis) to determine when the operation is complete.

        Parameters:
        axis - axis number [0..(size-1)]
        Returns:
        future Result at end of operation.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception

      • moveAxisAbsolute

        java.util.concurrent.Future<Result> moveAxisAbsolute(int axis,
                                                     double dest)
                                              throws java.io.IOException
        Absolute move, single axis.

        Move single axis to target destination. An asynchronous Future integer result is returned.

        The calling program should test this object for isDone to determine when the move is complete. The result is then available by calling get.

        Parameters:
        axis - axis number [0..(size-1)]
        dest - move destination, SCALED
        Returns:
        Future Result
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO Exception
        See Also:
        Result

      • setAxisDestination

        Result setAxisDestination(int axis,
                          double dest)
                   throws java.io.IOException
        Set target destination, single axis.

        This updates the axis destination and, possibly, initiates a move. The target destination is specified by the input dest.
        With most axes, the destination can be updated while a prior move is in progress. With some stages, if the destination cannot be updated, this method will return an BUSY status.

        Only the immediate command status is returned. Motion completion should be polled independently using getAxisIsReady.

        Parameters:
        axis - axis number [0..(size-1)]
        dest - move destination, SCALED
        Returns:
        Result at start of move.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - Generic IO exception
        See Also:
        Result
